choices.text: Junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu
Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu
Middle of the greater cornu
Middle of the body

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found in a state of partial suspension with a rope around his neck. The medical team suspects hanging as the cause of death. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist pays particular attention to the hyoid bone. The most likely finding in the hyoid bone in a case of hanging is a fracture at which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Junction of outer 1/3rd and inner 2/3rd of greater cornu

 

Option A:

 

Hyoid fractures are more common in manual strangulation > Hanging > Strangulation.

 

3 types:

 

  1. Inward compression fracture-seen in manual strangulation
  2. Anteroposterior compression fracture-seen in hanging
  3. Avulsion or tug or traction fracture

 

Most common site of hyoid fracture is junction of the outer 1/3rd and inner 2/3rd of greater cornu.

 

Fractures are rare below 40 years because of the elasticity of the cartilage and mobility of the joints. The fracture is common in persons above 40 years and involves the great horns, at the junction of inner two-thirds and outer one-third.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu - Less commonly involved in fractures due to hanging.

 

Option C: Middle of the greater cornu - This area is stronger and less likely to be fractured in hanging.

 

Option D: Middle of the body - The body of the hyoid bone is less commonly fractured in hanging compared to the junction of the greater cornu.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common anatomical site of hyoid bone fracture in cases of hanging, is most often at the junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 345

choices.text: Partial hanging
Complete hanging
Homicidal hanging
Suicidal hanging

questions.text: In forensic investigations of hanging deaths, the position of the body provides crucial information about the nature of the hanging. When a hanging is characterized by the feet touching the ground, it is classified as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial hanging

 

Option A:

 

Hanging where the feet are touching the ground is referred to as partial hanging. In this scenario, the body is not completely suspended in the air. Partial hanging can still result in death, often through vascular obstruction or other mechanisms, and does not necessarily imply a lower lethality. It is distinguished from complete hanging, where the body is fully suspended and no part of it touches the ground.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Complete hanging: This occurs when the entire weight of the body is suspended, with no support from the ground, which is not the case here.

 

Option C: Homicidal hanging: This classification is based on the manner of death (homicide) rather than the body's position.

 

Option D: Suicidal hanging: This refers to the intent (suicide) and not the physical position of the hanging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hanging is characterized by the body being suspended with the feet touching the ground, differentiating it from complete hanging where the body is fully suspended.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341

choices.text: Carotid arteries
Jugular vein
Airway above the level of thyroid
Airway below the level of thyroid

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found unresponsive in her apartment. The autopsy reveals bruising consistent with hand marks around her neck. The Forensic is explaining to the medical students that in cases of manual strangulation, the cause of death is typically due to the occlusion of what anatomical structure(s)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid arteries.

 

Option A:

 

In manual strangulation, the cause of death is most commonly due to the occlusion of the carotid arteries. When the carotid arteries are compressed, it leads to cerebral hypoxia or anoxia (lack of oxygen in the brain), resulting in unconsciousness and eventually death if the pressure is sustained. The rapid decrease in cerebral blood flow due to the compression of these arteries is a critical factor in fatalities due to manual strangulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Jugular vein - While compression of the jugular veins can contribute to death by preventing venous return from the brain, it is not the primary cause of death in manual strangulation.

 

Option C: Airway above the level of thyroid - Compression of the airway can lead to asphyxia, but in manual strangulation, the occlusion of the carotid arteries is more immediately life-threatening.

 

Option D: Airway below the level of thyroid - Similar to option c, this can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism of death in manual strangulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asphyxia produced by compression of the neck by human hands is called manual strangulation or Throttling. However, death occurs due to occlusion of carotid arteries. Occlusion of airway plays minor role.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 346

choices.text: Caffey syndrome
Depressed gag reflex
Accidental choking
Both B and C

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, known to have a history of alcohol abuse, is found deceased at his dining table. He was eating hurriedly after consuming a significant amount of alcohol. The forensic expert is discussing the case with medical students and explains the possible causes of death in such a scenario. Which of the following is not a correct association in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caffey syndrome.

 

Option A:

 

Caffey syndrome: It is also known as 'Battered baby syndrome' or 'Child abuse syndrome'. A Battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. In addition to physical injury, there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. This is a rare pediatric disease characterized by inflammation and abnormal growth of bones and is not related to the scenario described. This condition is unrelated to sudden death in an alcohol-intoxicated individual who was eating hastily.

 

This case involves café coronary, not Caffey syndrome. In café coronary, the gag reflex is diminished (option B), and it is considered a specific type of accidental choking (option C) that can lead to sudden death. Therefore, both options B and C contribute to the cause of death in this scenario. The question, however, is asking which statement is NOT correct."

 

Cafe coronary: This is a condition in which a healthy but grossly intoxicated person, who begins a meal, suddenly turns blue, coughs violently, then collapses and dies. Death appears to be due to sudden heart attack, but at autopsy a large piece of poorly chewed food may be found obstructing the larynx. Due to intoxication the gag reflex is depressed. This is an accidental form of choking.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Depressed gag reflex - In an alcohol-intoxicated individual, a depressed gag reflex is a plausible factor, as alcohol can depress the central nervous system, making accidental choking more likely.

 

Option C: Accidental choking - This is a likely cause of death in this scenario. Rapid eating, especially when combined with alcohol intoxication that depresses protective airway reflexes, can lead to choking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While in Caffey syndrome/ Battered baby syndrome/ Child abuse syndrome, child is the one who has received repetitive physical injuries and the Cafe coronary is a condition in which a healthy but grossly intoxicated person, who begins a meal, suddenly turns blue, coughs violently, then collapses and dies due to depressed gag reflex and accidental choking.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 365

choices.text: Congestion
Petechiae
Cyanosis
Pulselessness

questions.text: During a lecture on asphyxial deaths, a forensic medicine professor outlines the classical triad of signs typically associated with asphyxia. A student asks which of the following is not included in this classical triad. Which is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulselessness.

 

Option D:

 

The classical triad of asphyxia includes congestion, petechiae, and cyanosis. These signs are indicative of the physiological changes that occur due to hypoxia and the mechanics of asphyxial deaths. Pulselessness is not a part of this triad; it is a sign of death itself and not specific to asphyxia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congestion and edema of the face and visceral congestion due to raised venous pressure.

 

Option B: Petechiae - Petechial hemorrhages on the face, conjunctiva, subpleura or subepicardium (Tardieu spots).

 

Option C: Cyanosis - Bluish discoloration of skin, face (particularly lips and ears), nailbeds, mucous membranes, or internal organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classical triad of asphyxia includes congestion, petechiae, and cyanosis

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 138-139

choices.text: Bleaching-Soddening-Wrinkling-Degloving
Soddening-Wrinkling-Bleaching-Degloving
Wrinkling-Soddening-Bleaching-Degloving
Wrinkling-Bleaching-Soddening-Degloving

questions.text: A group of students are learning about the post-mortem changes in drowning victims. The instructor emphasizes the importance of understanding the sequence of skin changes for accurate assessment in drowning cases. Which among the following is the correct sequence of skin changes in drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wrinkling-Soddening-Bleaching-Degloving
 

Explanation:

 

Washerwoman's hand-It is seen in case of drowning. The skin of the palms and soles are characterized by thickening, bleached, sodden, and corrugated appearance.

 

Time of appearance after submersion:

 

  • Wrinkling - After 3 hr of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water) - After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching - After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Degloving (Peeling)- after 72 hours of immersion

 

It is first seen on the fingertips in two to four hours and spreads to the palm and the backs of the fingers, and the back of the hand, in that order in about twenty-four hours. Similar progress and changes are seen in the skin of the foot, but when shoes are worn, it takes almost twice as long.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of skin changes in drowning, which typically follows the order of wrinkling, soddening, bleaching, and finally degloving/ peeling.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368

choices.text: Postmortem drowning
Antemortem unconscious drowning
Antemortem conscious drowning
Both A and B

questions.text: A forensic resident is presenting a case of a drowning victim to her colleagues. The victim was found unconscious in a swimming pool and was later pronounced dead. The autopsy revealed significant findings in the lungs. The resident discusses the development of 'Edema Aquosum' or immersion pulmonary edema in drowning cases. Which scenario is most likely associated with the development of Edema Aquosum?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antemortem unconscious drowning
 

Option B:

 

Edema aquosum: When a person submerges in unconscious state, there is no violent effort for respiration. Some water may enter into the lungs bed passively leading to passive edema. In this situation there will be mere flooding of lungs with water but formation of column of froth in the air passage does not occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Postmortem drowning - Postmortem submersion does not involve active inhalation of water, as the victim is already dead and lacks respiratory function. Therefore, the development of significant pulmonary edema is less likely in postmortem drowning

 

Option C: Antemortem conscious drowning - Emphysema aquosum: When a person submerges in conscious state and due to violent respiratory effort following increased pressure due to forced expiration ballooning of the lungs occur and a column of froth is formed in the air passage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the person is unconscious at the time of drowning, edema aquosum develops. It is a state of mere flooding of lungs with airless water and no formation of froth. Emphysema aquosum develops only when the conscious victim of drowning struggles for survival.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 369

choices.text: Antemortem drowning
Postmortem drowning
Prolonged immersion in water
All the above

questions.text: During an autopsy of a woman who was found dead in a river, the forensic pathologist notices the presence of water in the woman's feet. The medical students observing the autopsy are asked about the significance of this finding. What does the presence of water in the feet during autopsy typically indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged immersion in water.

 

Option C:

 

The presence of water in the feet during an autopsy is indicative of prolonged immersion in water. This finding is not specific to antemortem or postmortem drowning and can be seen in any case where the body has been submerged for an extended period, regardless of the cause of death.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Antemortem drowning - While this could be a possibility, the presence of water in the feet alone is not specific enough to confirm antemortem drowning.

 

Option B: Postmortem drowning - This term is usually used to describe a body that has been immersed after death; the presence of water in the feet is not specific to this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hand/feet: Skin of the limbs becomes sodden, thickened, wrinkled and white in color (fingertip-2 hrs, back of hand-24 hrs, palm & sole - 2 days, degloving-3 to 4 days). Not a specific sign of drowning. It occurs due to prolonged immersion in water.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368

choices.text: Natural
Accidental
Suicidal
Homicidal

questions.text: A man is found dead in his home with food particles obstructing his airway. The death appears to be due to choking. The forensic examiner is discussing the manner of death in such cases with the medical students. What is the most likely manner of death in choking?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Accidental.

 

Option B:

 

Choking is a form of asphyxia caused by an obstruction within the air passages, usually between the pharynx and bifurcation of trachea. The individual develops a sore throat hoarseness, respiratory difficulty and then suddenly collapses. It is commonly associated with alcohol intoxication, neurological injury, or senility.

 

The manner of death in choking is most commonly accidental. Choking typically occurs when a foreign object, like food, accidentally obstructs the airway, leading to asphyxia.

 

Cause of Death:

 

  1. Cardiac inhibition is the common cause.
  2. Asphyxia.
  3. Laryngeal spasm
  4. Delayed death may result from pneumonia, lung abscess or bronchiectasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Natural - Choking is not considered a natural cause of death.

 

Option C: Suicidal - It is rare. The victims are usually mental patients (dementia or psychoses) or prisoners. For this a foreign body is thrust into the throat.

 

Option D: Homicidal - Choking as a mode of infanticide may be caused by stuffing a wad of paper or cloth into the pharynx or larynx. It is very rare and i practicable only when the victim is suffering from disability or disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manner of death in cases of choking is most commonly accidental, due to the unintentional obstruction of the airway.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 363

choices.text: Manual strangulation
Ligature strangulation
Hanging
Mugging

questions.text: A decomposed body is found in a room. Upon examination, the forensic resident notes that the face shows postmortem purging, but a ligature mark on the neck is still visible. The resident asks the medical students about the most likely cause of death in this case. What could be the possible cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hanging

 

Option C:

 

In hanging the ligature mark is dry, hard, parchmentized, and avascular. Hence, this site of ligature mark is not easily obliterated due to decomposition.

 

Postmortem purging (fluid and blood from orifices) is consistent with the advanced decomposition. Postmortem purge refers to the leakage of blood-tinged fluid from the nose, mouth, or other orifices after death, particularly during decomposition. It's caused by gas buildup and pressure from putrefaction forcing fluids from the lungs, stomach, or upper airways out through orifices.

 

Hanging (self-suspension) is that form of asphyxia which is caused by suspension of the body by a ligature which encircles the neck, the constricting force being the weight of the body.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Manual strangulation - OR throttling: When human fingers, palms or hands are used to compress the neck, so no ligature mark.

 

Option B: Ligature strangulation - When ligature material is used to compress the neck. Could potentially leave a mark, but the pattern may differ from that seen in hanging. As it is not dry and hard, hence it will fade in decomposed body.

 

Option D: Mugging - Holding the neck of victim in the bend of the elbow or knee of the assailant. It is an attack, usually from behind, and may leave no external or internal injury mark. It is also known as chokehold. This hold is not permitted in wrestling, because of its danger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a visible ligature mark on the neck, even in an advanced decomposed body is indicative of death by hanging.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338

choices.text: Towards the site of knot
Opposite the site of knot
Both the angles
No salivary stain found

questions.text: A Forensic Expert is examining a body found with a ligature around the neck in an atypical position. Notably, there is dribbling of saliva on the body. He asks the medical students observing the autopsy about the expected pattern of saliva in cases of atypical hanging. Where is dribbling of saliva typically seen in a case of atypical hanging?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opposite the site of knot

 

Option B:

 

Dribbling of saliva: most important and surest sign of antemortem hanging. Excessive salivation occurs when the person is alive, due to pressure and friction caused by ligature material on the submandibular glands (pterygopalatine ganglion). Dribbling of saliva occurs from the angle of mouth, which is at a lower level, i.e. from angle opposite to the side of knot. When the knot is on the nape of the neck, it occurs across the middle of lower lip

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Towards the site of knot - This is less common, as gravity tends to draw the saliva away from the higher side where the knot is located.

 

Option C: Both the angles - Saliva typically dribbles down the lowest point due to gravity, which is usually opposite to the knot.

 

Option D: No salivary stain found - Salivary stains are often present in hanging cases due to loss of control over salivary glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of atypical hanging, the dribbling of saliva is typically observed opposite to the site of the knot, influenced by the position of the body and the effects of gravity.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 344

choices.text: Fracture of hyoid bone
Fracture of thyroid cartilage
Bruising in the strap muscles of neck
Deep congestion of face with petechial hemorrhage

questions.text: A forensic resident is examining the autopsy findings of a deceased individual who was discovered under suspicious circumstances. The investigation suggests possible foul play, and he is looking for specific clues to determine the cause of death. Among the findings, he notices fractures in the neck area. Which of the following autopsy findings is not commonly associated with ligature strangulation, raising the possibility of a different cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture of hyoid bone

 

Option A:

 

Hyoid bone fracture is most commonly seen in throttling, followed by hanging and least likely in ligature strangulation.

 

Ligature Strangulation - PM findings –

 

External –

 

  • A ligature mark run transversely, completely encircling the neck, usually at the level of thyroid or below it.
  • Peri-ligature injuries and hemorrhage are present.
  • Intense congestion and deep cyanosis. Asphyxial signs are more in comparison to hanging.
  • Signs of struggle in the form of abrasion, contusions over face and other parts of the body.

 

Internal-

 

  • Severe engorgement and hemorrhage into the tissue in and above the area of compression.
  • Extensive bruising and laceration of adjacent muscles of the neck.
  • Bruising of the tonsils, salivary glands, and root of tongue.
  • Blood-stained froths in larynx, trachea, and bronchi with congested mucosa.
  • Fracture of thyroid cartilage is more common (especially superior horn)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fracture of thyroid cartilage - is more common esp. in one or both the superior horns.

 

Option C: Bruising in the strap muscles of neck - Extensive bruising and laceration of adjacent muscles of the neck.

 

Option D: Deep congestion of face with petechial hemorrhage - Severe engorgement and hemorrhage into the tissue in and above the area of compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligature strangulation is characterized by a transverse ligature mark encircling the neck, peri-ligature injuries, intense congestion, and signs of struggle. Internally, it is marked by severe tissue engorgement, bruising of neck muscles, and often the fracture of the thyroid cartilage, especially its superior horn.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 357

choices.text: Thoracic cavity
Abdominal cavity
Cranial cavity
Neck

questions.text: A Medical officer is conducting an autopsy on a victim of a suspicious death. He is examining various findings to determine the cause of death. In cases of violent asphyxia, which of the following structures should be open at last?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neck

 

Option D:

 

In cases of violent asphyxia, the neck should be examined last during an autopsy. This approach is critical to preserve the integrity of the structures within the neck, such as the thyroid cartilage, hyoid bone, larynx, and blood vessels. Opening the neck last helps to avoid artificially disrupting these structures, which could potentially mask or alter the signs of trauma related to the cause of death. Accurate assessment of these structures is vital in cases of violent asphyxia, where neck injuries play a significant role in determining the cause and manner of death.

 

This is also done to obtain a bloodless field in the neck

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Thoracic cavity: While important, opening it last is not crucial for preserving evidence in cases of violent asphyxia.

 

Option B: Abdominal cavity: Similarly, opening this last is not specific to violent asphyxia cases.

 

Option C: Cranial cavity: Important in traumatic deaths, but in violent asphyxia, neck examination is more crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the neck last during an autopsy in cases of violent asphyxia to ensure the preservation and accurate assessment of vital structures that are crucial in establishing the cause and manner of death.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 354

choices.text: Washerwoman's hand
Water in the stomach
Cutis Anserina
Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was found dead in a lake. On forensic examination, the medical examiner noted certain findings to determine whether the death was due to antemortem drowning or postmortem submersion. Which of the following findings is most indicative of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands

 

Option D:

 

Grass, gravel, mud, sand, weeds or aquatic vegetations held firmly in clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm is a vital proof of antemortem drowning. This sign suggests active movements while the person was still alive and immersed in water. The material clenched in the hands even indicates the place of drowning.

 

Damaged nails and abraded fingers showing sand, mud, or other materials under the nails due to struggle has the same significance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Washerwoman's hand - This refers to the pruney appearance of the skin after prolonged exposure to water and can occur in both antemortem and postmortem cases.

 

 

Option B: Water in the stomach - While water in the stomach can be seen in drowning victims, it is not conclusive of antemortem drowning, as water can enter the stomach postmortem in submerged bodies. But if Mud and algae in stomach and intestine, then this is sure sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. Cutis Anserina:  Cutis anserina, also known as "goose flesh" or "goose bumps," can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning cases. It is characterized by a puckered appearance of the skin with hair standing erect due to the contraction of the erector pili muscles.

 

In cases of antemortem drowning, cutis anserina can occur due to the body's physiological response to the cold water. When a person is alive and submerged in cold water, the erector pili muscles contract in response to the cold, causing the hair to stand on end. 

 

Cutis anserina can also be observed in postmortem drowning cases. After death, rigor mortis sets in, affecting all skeletal muscles, including the erector pili muscles. This postmortem rigidity can cause the hair to stand on end, giving the appearance of cutis anserina

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands: This is a classic sign of struggle before death. It suggests the victim was alive and trying to save himself, possibly grabbing vegetation in panic—a strong vital reaction indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368

choices.text: Pupil is dilated at the site of the knot
Pupil is constricted at the site of the knot
Pupil is dilated opposite to the site of the knot
Pupil is constricted opposite to the site of the knot

questions.text: As a forensic expert, you are visiting a crime scene and examining a body found hanging. Upon close examination of the face, a notable finding related to the pupils is observed. Out of the below-mentioned options, which one describes this finding, known as La Facie Sympathique?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pupil is dilated at the site of the knot

 

Explanation:

 

PM finding of hanging -

 

Dilated pupils: If the knot presses on cervical sympathetic, eye of the same side may remain open and pupil is dilated (la facie sympathetique). It indicates antemortem hanging.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

La Facie Sympathique, observed in cases of antemortem hanging, is characterized by the dilatation of the pupil at the site of the knot.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 344

choices.text: Acute Pulmonary edema
Myocardial infarction
Laryngeal spasm
Cerebral hypoxia

questions.text: A patient was found unresponsive near a pool and later pronounced dead. Despite resuscitation efforts, no significant water was found in the lungs upon autopsy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this scenario, often described as "dry drowning"?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal spasm

 

Option C:

 

Dry drowning –

 

In this water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasm induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx. Seen in 1–2% of cases. Death may be extremely rapid and time elapsed is insufficient for typical drowning to occur.

 

Two mechanisms have been postulated:

 

  1. Reflex cardiac arrest due to vasovagal stimulation.
  2. Laryngeal spasm and airway closure causing lethal hypoxemia.

 

In these cases, autopsy findings and tests for drowning are negative, and the lung fields are dry.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acute Pulmonary edema - While pulmonary edema can occur in drowning, it is not the primary cause in dry drowning, which is characterized by minimal water in the lungs.

 

Option B: Myocardial infarction - This is an unlikely cause of death in the context of drowning, especially in younger individuals without underlying heart disease.

 

Option D: Cerebral hypoxia - While cerebral hypoxia is a consequence of prolonged asphyxia, in the context of dry drowning, the direct cause leading to hypoxia is laryngeal spasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal spasm as the primary cause of death in cases of dry drowning, which is characterized by airway obstruction due to reflexive closure of the vocal cords in response to water contact with the larynx.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 373

choices.text: Denatured
Diluted
Both denatured and diluted
Not affected

questions.text: During the autopsy of a victim suspected to have drowned in freshwater, alterations in the lung surfactant were noted. What changes occur to pulmonary surfactant in freshwater drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Denatured

 

Option A:

 

Fresh water alters or denatures the protective surfactant which lines the alveolar wall, while sea water dilutes or washes it away.

 

Pathophysiology –

 

  • The denaturing of surfactant can continue even after a person is successfully resuscitated.
  • Loss or inactivation of pulmonary surfactant (lipoprotein) and alveolar collapse decrease lung compliance, resulting in severe ventilation perfusion mismatch.
  • The defective functioning of surfactant leads to pulmonary oedema with transudation of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar spaces, hypoxia, and secondary metabolic acidosis.
  • The serum potassium increases (a powerful myocardial toxin). Cardiac arrhythmias leading to ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Diluted - This is observed in sea water drowning, surfactant are diluted and washed away.

 

Pathophysiology of Sea water drowning –

 

  • Due to the high salinity, water is drawn from the blood into the lung tissue, and produces severe pulmonary oedema, and hypernatremia. This causes hemoconcentration.
  • Heart failure may occur due to myocardial anoxia and increased viscosity of blood. Slow death occurs from asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fresh water alters or denatures the protective surfactant which lines the alveolar wall, while sea water dilutes it or washes it away.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 387

choices.text: Cervical vertebrae
Thoracic vertebrae
Lumbar vertebrae
Both thoracic and lumbar vertebrae

questions.text: During a seminar on forensic findings in asphyxial deaths, a pathologist discusses a case of a suspected hanging. The body showed peculiar patterns of postmortem hemorrhage. For educational purposes, the pathologist asks the residents to identify the typical locations of these hemorrhages, known as Simon's hemorrhages, which are associated with hanging. Where are Simon's hemorrhages most commonly found?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) lumbar vertebrae

 

Option C:

 

Simon's hemorrhages are postmortem findings associated with hanging and are usually located in the soft tissues overlying the lumbar vertebrae. There is the bleeding into the outer layers of the intervertebral discs (red stripes in between the vertebral bodies) of lumbar vertebrae. May be seen in bodies suspended for a long time.

 

It may also be seen in other traumatic elongation or overextension of spinal column (e.g. traffic accidents), drowning and putrefaction (‘false positive’).

 

Explanation:

 

 A: Cervical vertebrae and B: Thoracic vertebrae - These are not the typical locations for Simon's hemorrhages in cases of hanging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simon's hemorrhages as a postmortem finding in cases of hanging, characteristically located in the soft tissues overlying lumbar vertebrae.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 344

choices.text: Complex suicide
Complicated suicide
Suicide pact
Parasuicide

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is found deceased with evidence of multiple lethal self-inflicted injuries. The decedent consumed a toxic substance, inflicted cuts to his wrists, and subsequently hanged himself. The forensic term for this type of suicide is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex suicide

 

Option A:

 

Complex suicide refers to a scenario where an individual uses multiple methods to end their own life. The term indicates that the person has employed more than one lethal means, which in this case includes poisoning, cutting the wrists, and hanging. This approach is often taken to ensure death, even if one method fails.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Complicated suicide - When during the original suicidal method, unintentional trauma occurs which leads to death, e.g. a person hanging himself from a branch of tree, the branch breaks and the person dies due to complications of fall.

 

Option C: Suicide pact - This refers to a mutual agreement between two or more people to die by suicide together.

 

Option D: Parasuicide - (attempted suicide or pseudicide), a term coined by Norman Kreitman, is a conscious often impulsive, manipulative act, undertaken to get rid of an intolerable situation. It is a non-fatal act in which a person deliberately causes injury to himself or ingests any drug in excess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While, Complex suicide is Person plans more than one method of suicide to make sure that death will occur and complicated suicide is during original suicidal method, unintentional trauma leading to death.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 345

choices.text: Bansdola
Mugging
Garrotting
Overlying

questions.text: A forensic resident is reviewing historical methods of execution and encounters a photograph from the early 20th century depicting a method of strangulation. This method, known as the "Spanish Windlass," involves a mechanism that is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Garrotting

 

Option C:

 

Garroting: Strangulation is caused by compression of the neck by a ligature which is quickly tightened by twisting it with a lever (rod, stick or ruler) known as Spanish windlass, which results in sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. Garroting as a mode of execution was practiced in Spain, Portugal, and Turkey. An iron collar was tightened by a screw for strangulation.

 

 

A Garrote

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bansdola - A bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. Both the ends are tied with a rope due to which the victim is squeezed to death. When a foot or knee is placed across the front of throat and pressed while the victim is lying on ground, same condition will follow. If a stick or foot is used, a bruise is seen in the center, across the trachea corresponding to the width of the object used.

 

Option B: Mugging - Strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of elbow or knee of the assailant. It is an attack, usually from behind, and may leave no external or internal injury mark. It is also known as chokehold. This hold is not permitted in wrestling, because of its danger.

 

Option D: Overlying - This term generally refers to the accidental suffocation of an infant, often when an adult rolls over onto the child during sleep, and is not related to execution methods. This results from compression of the chest, nose, and mouth, so as to prevent breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Garroting is the one of the methods of carrying out death sentence, also known as Spanish windlass

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 359

choices.text: Gagging
Overlaying
Smothering
Choking

questions.text: A medical examiner is conducting a forensic training session discussing various asphyxial deaths. They present a scenario asking the trainees to identify which method of asphyxiation is almost always considered homicidal in nature. Which of the following is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gagging

 

Option A:

 

Gagging - It is a form of asphyxia which results from pushing a gag (rolled up cloth or paper balls) into the mouth, sufficiently deep to block the pharynx. It combines the features of smothering and choking. Initially, the airway may be patent through nose, but collections of saliva, excessive mucus with edema of pharynx and nasal mucosa causes complete obstruction.

 

Postmortem findings

 

  1. Signs of asphyxial death - Subconjunctival hemorrhages without cutaneous petechiae may be seen.
  2. Presence of gag in mouth or respiratory tract.
  3. In an epileptic, tongue may show bite marks or bruising.
  4. Injuries to nose and mouth with seepage of blood into the back of throat.

 

Medico-legal aspects

 

  • Almost always homicidal, and the victim is usually an infant or an elderly person.
  • Gagging is usually resorted to prevent the victim from shouting for help; death is usually unintended.
  • Gags have been used to suppress screams by victims using a painful method of suicide (e.g. self- immolation).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Overlaying - This term generally refers to the accidental suffocation of an infant, often when an adult rolls over onto the child during sleep, and is not related to execution methods. This results from compression of the chest, nose, and mouth, so as to prevent breathing.

 

Option C: Smothering - Can be homicidal, suicidal, or accidental, depending on the circumstances. It is a form of asphyxia caused by mechanical occlusion of external air passages, i.e. the nose and mouth by hand, cloth, plastic bag, or other material.

 

Option D: Choking - Most commonly an accidental event. It is a form of asphyxia caused by an obstruction within the air-passages by a foreign object, like coin, fruit seed, toffees, candies, fish, or any other material

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gagging as an asphyxial death mechanism that is almost always associated with homicidal actions due to its forced nature.

 

Additional Information

 

Asphyxial Conditions –

 

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 362

choices.text: Traumatic asphyxia
Postural asphyxia
Drowning
Choking

questions.text: In a lecture on asphyxial deaths, the instructor discusses various positions that the body might be found in that can suggest the mechanism of death. The "Jack- knife" position, characterized by the body being found in a piked position with the chest and knees drawn up, is most typically associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postural asphyxia

 

Option B:

 

Postural asphyxia occurs when the position of the body interferes with respiration, often due to external pressure or force. The "Jack-knife" position can be a result of the body being compressed or forced into a bent position in such a manner that his thighs and the knees are driven against his chest, which can impair breathing and lead to asphyxia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Traumatic asphyxia - This typically results from a heavy force or pressure to the chest or abdomen like in a stampede or collapse of a building.

 

Option C: Drowning - The position of the body is not specifically indicative of drowning, which is a type of asphyxia caused by inhalation of fluid.

 

Option D: Choking - This refers to an obstruction of the airway from within, such as by food, and is not typically associated with body position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Jack-knife" position is most commonly associated with postural asphyxia, indicating a death where the body's position has compromised the ability to breathe.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 364

choices.text: Wet drowning
Dry drowning
Post immersion syndrome
Immersion syndrome

questions.text: A 19-year-old male is found unconscious and pulseless next to a community pool after diving into cold water on a hot day. Resuscitation efforts were initiated, but the patient was pronounced dead on arrival at the emergency department. Autopsy did not reveal significant findings in the lungs or airways. Which of the following best describes the likely cause of death in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immersion syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Immersion syndrome (Hydrocution, submersion inhibition or cold-water drowning): It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac dysrhythmias on sudden contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than body temperature.

 

Vagal stimulation leading to asystolic cardiac arrest (‘diving reflex’), or ventricular fibrillation secondary to QT prolongation after a massive release of catecholamine on contact with cold water. The resultant loss of consciousness leads to secondary drowning.

 

The findings of typical drowning are absent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Wet drowning - Water is inhaled into the lungs and the victim has severe chest pain (seen in 80–90% of cases). It is also known as primary drowning.

 

2 types –

 

 

In both fresh water and saltwater drowning, there is terminal pulmonary edema.

 

Option B: Dry drowning – In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasm induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.

 

Option C: Post immersion syndrome – Near drowning or secondary drowning – This describes complications that occur after an individual has been rescued from a near-drowning event. Here, death is caused by complications or sequelae (e.g. ARDS, pneumonia, sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, cerebral edema and DIC).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immersion syndrome, also known as hydrocution, is characterized by sudden death due to cardiac arrest shortly after immersion in cold water, without signs of drowning. The rapid cooling of the skin triggers a vagal reflex, which can lead to arrhythmia and cardiac arrest.

 

Ref – Reddy 33/e. Pg 366

choices.text: Upper lobes
Lower lobes
Interlobar surface
Lingula

questions.text: A medical examiner is presenting an autopsy case of a suspected drowning victim to a group of medical residents. Upon examination of the lungs, the examiner points out specific hemorrhagic spots which are crucial in confirming the diagnosis of drowning. These spots, known as Paltauf’s hemorrhages, are most commonly found in which part of the lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lower lobes

 

Option B:

 

Paltauf's hemorrhages are typically found in the lower lobes of the lungs. They are considered a characteristic finding in cases of drowning, representing areas of acute alveolar damage and hemorrhage. These hemorrhages result from the rapid increase in intravascular pressure during the process of drowning, which is often most pronounced in the lower lobes due to gravity-dependent blood flow.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Upper lobes - While hemorrhages can occur here, they are less commonly associated with the pattern of Paltauf's hemorrhages in drowning.

 

Option C: Interlobar surface - This area is not typically associated with the specific hemorrhages seen in drowning.

 

Option D: Lingula - A specific part of the left lung that is not typically cited as the common location for Paltauf's hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paltauf's hemorrhages as a postmortem finding in drowning cases, typically located in the lower lobes of the lungs due to increased intravascular pressure.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 369

choices.text: 15%
25%
35%
40%

questions.text: In a forensic lecture, the instructor discusses the Gettler test, a diagnostic tool used in the investigation of drowning deaths. The test measures chloride levels in the heart's ventricles. For the Gettler test to be considered significant in supporting a diagnosis of drowning, the difference in chloride content between the right and left ventricles should be at least:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25%

 

Explanation:

 

The Gettler test is significant in diagnosing drowning when there is a difference of approximately 25% in chloride content between the right and left ventricles. This test is based on the premise that during drowning, especially in saltwater, the absorption of water leads to changes in the electrolyte balance in the blood, which is reflected in the chloride content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gettler test: Normally, the chloride content of the right and left side of heart is nearly same, about 600 mg/100 ml. If difference is 25 mg% or more, it is suggestive of antemortem drowning.

 

Ref – Reddy 33/e. Pg 373

choices.text: Masturbation
Frotteurism
Voyeurism
Transvestism

questions.text: A resident in psychiatry is reviewing a case of death with the help of his colleague from forensic medicine, where the cause of death is due to autoerotic practices. In this context, which of the following sexual behaviors is most commonly associated with autoerotic asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Masturbation

 

Option A:

 

Autoerotic asphyxia is most commonly associated with masturbation. This practice involves self-strangulation or other methods of reducing oxygen flow to the brain during sexual arousal, often during solitary masturbation. The purpose is to enhance sexual pleasure by adding an element of hypoxia, but it carries significant risks including accidental death.

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • Sexual asphyxias (autoerotic asphyxia; asphyxiophilia) are very rare. Partial asphyxia caused by pressure on carotid vessels, or partial obstruction of air-passages causes cerebral disturbances and may lead to hallucinations of an erotic nature in some men.
  • The degree of asphyxia produced by mechanical means is controlled, but in some cases death occurs accidentally. These cases are associated with some form of abnormal sexual behaviour, usually masochism and transvestism.
  • The victims are almost always males, and usually young.
  • The scene is usually the victim's own house; the bedroom, bathroom, basement, or attic are usually selected, and the door is locked from the inside. Adult males with homosexual preferences tend to carry out the procedure in pairs as a means of protection from accidental death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Frotteurism - It is the act of obtaining sexual arousal and gratification by rubbing of one’s genitals against a non-consenting person in public places. It is usually seen in males. This is an offence and punishable under Sec. 290 IPC (fine of Rs 200) and Sec. 291 IPC imprisonment for 6 months and/or fine) for creating public nuisance

 

Option C: Voyeurism - Also known as Scoptophilia. This involves sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting individuals, typically strangers, naked or engaged in sexual activity. It is commonly seen in males. It occurs in case of sociopathic personality disorder, and such individuals may commit sexual crimes. Under Sec. 354-C IPC, voyeurism is a punishable offence, for first offence imprisonment from 1–3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable), and for 2nd offence, imprisonment is for 3–7 years and fine (cognizable and non-bailable).

 

Option D: Transvestism refers to the practice of dressing and acting in a style or manner traditionally associated with the opposite sex. The degree of asphyxia produced by mechanical means is controlled, but in some cases, death occurs accidentally, but the most common association of Autoerotic asphyxia is with masturbation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Masturbation (onanism / ipsation / autoeroticism) is the deliberate self-stimulation which effects sexual arousal. Mild masturbatory exercises are common both to men and women and are of little importance.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 375, 432

choices.text: Aquatic unicellular algae
Has an extracellular coat composed of magnesium
Acid digestion technique is used to extract diatoms
Presence of diatoms in the femoral bone marrow is an indication of antemortem inhalation of water

questions.text: During a forensic lecture, a discussion is held regarding the use of diatoms in the investigation of drowning deaths. Which of the following statements about diatoms is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Has an extracellular coat composed of magnesium

 

Option B:

 

Diatoms are aquatic unicellular algae with a characteristic silica shell, rather than a coat composed of magnesium. They are used in forensic pathology to help confirm a diagnosis of drowning when found in body tissues, as they would only be present following antemortem inhalation or ingestion of water containing these organisms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Aquatic unicellular algae- This is correct; diatoms are indeed aquatic unicellular algae.

 

Option C: Acid digestion technique is used to extract diatoms - This statement is correct; the acid digestion technique is used to dissolve tissue and release diatoms for analysis.

 

Option D: Presence of diatoms in the femoral bone marrow is an indication of antemortem inhalation of water - This is correct and is used as a confirmatory test for drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diatoms have a silica shell, not magnesium, and are used forensically to confirm drowning when found in body tissues like bone marrow.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 372

choices.text: Total asphyxia is produced due to fresh water
Laryngeal spasm causing vagal inhibition
Hemoconcentration of blood caused by the osmotic effect
Hemodilution resulting in hyperkalemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was found unresponsive in a freshwater lake. During the emergency department resuscitation, the patient was noted to have ventricular fibrillation. In the context of freshwater drowning, the emergency physician discusses the potential pathophysiological mechanism for this arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of ventricular fibrillation in freshwater drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemodilution resulting in hyperkalemia

 

Option D:

 

In fresh water drowning, hyperkalemia occurs. This is because the hypotonic fresh water quickly diffuses into the bloodstream, leading to hemolysis, which is the destruction of red blood cells. As red blood cells burst, potassium is released into the extracellular space, causing an increase in serum potassium levels, which is hyperkalemia. This sudden increase in potassium can be dangerous as it may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Total asphyxia produced due to fresh water - While asphyxia does occur in drowning, it is not the direct cause of ventricular fibrillation.

 

Option B: Laryngeal spasm causing vagal inhibition - This can occur in drowning, but it does not typically lead to ventricular fibrillation.

 

Option C: Hemoconcentration of blood caused by the osmotic effect - This is more typical of saltwater drowning, not freshwater drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemodilution resulting in hyperkalemia is a key mechanism leading to ventricular fibrillation in freshwater drowning cases.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 367

choices.text: Homicidal hanging
Suicidal hanging
Judicial hanging
Accidental hanging

questions.text: You are a forensic medicine expert collaborating with a legal team to analyze a recent case involving lynching. In the context of forensic terminology, which category best describes lynching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homicidal hanging

 

Option A:

 

Lynching is a form of homicidal hanging. A suspect, an accused or an enemy is overpowered by several persons, acting jointly and illegally, and hung him by means of a rope from a tree or some similar object. It was prevalent in North America, where it was practiced by whites on blacks

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B: Suicidal hanging: This option is incorrect because lynching involves the killing of another person, not self-inflicted harm.

 

Option C: Judicial hanging: This option is incorrect because judicial hanging is a legal execution carried out by authorities, whereas lynching is extrajudicial and illegal.

 

Option D: Accidental hanging: This option is incorrect because lynching is a deliberate and intentional act, not an accidental occurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lynching is a form of homicidal hanging, where a group of individuals unlawfully takes another person's life through violent means.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 346

choices.text: Body is completely suspended
Knot on the back of the head
Knot near the right ear
Some part of the body touching the ground

questions.text: 30 A forensic pathologist is investigating a case where an individual was found deceased in a suspended state. The body's position and the ligature mark characteristics are important for determining the type of hanging. Which of the following best describes atypical hanging?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Knot near the right ear

 

Option C:

 

Atypical hanging: Knot of ligature is anywhere other than on the occiput.

 

Hanging Classification –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Body is completely suspended - Complete Hanging - Body is fully suspended and no part of body touches the ground. Constricting force is weight of the body.

 

Option B: Knot on the back of the head - Typical hanging - When the point of suspension is placed centrally over the occiput, i.e. the knot is at the nape of neck on the back

 

Option D: Some part of the body touching the ground - Incomplete or partial hanging: Lower part of the body is touching the ground (toes or feet touching the ground) or in sitting, kneeling, lying down or prone position. Weight of the head acts as the constricting force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atypical hanging refers to a situation in which the knot of the ligature is not positioned at the occiput (back of the neck) but rather on the right or left side of the neck or at the front of the neck.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338

choices.text: Brain
Femur (thigh bone)
Muscle
Lungs

questions.text: In forensic investigations, particularly in suspected drowning cases, the diatom test is crucial to establish the cause of death. Diatoms are microscopic algae present in water bodies and can enter the body during drowning. Considering the distribution of diatoms in a drowned body, which of the following is considered the ideal sample for a diatom test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femur (thigh bone)

 

Explanation:

 

The femur (thigh bone) is considered the ideal sample for a diatom test in suspected antemortem drowning cases. This helps to confirm whether the individual was alive at the time of submersion.

 

Diatom test –

 

  • Diatoms belong to the class Bacillariophyceae and are microscopic unicellular algae which secrete silicon skeletons called frustules. They are chemically inert and almost indestructible, resistant to strong acids.
  • During drowning, diatoms (size up to 60 μ) enter the circulation via the lungs through the ruptured alveolar walls, lymph channels and pulmonary veins into the left heart and then into general circulation, when the person is alive.
  • The presence of diatoms in the lung substance, blood stream, brain, liver, kidneys, sternum, bone marrow of femur (best site for analysis) or humerus or in the skeletal muscle has been claimed to be suggestive proof of antemortem drowning.
  • Since diatoms resist putrefaction, diatom tests may have some value in examination of decomposed bodies.
  • The test is negative in dead bodies thrown in water and in dry drowning.
  • A water sample is collected at the time of body retrieval in a clean container and similarity of different species of diatom is compared.
  • Interpretation - The presence of diatoms supports the diagnosis of drowning, while the absence of diatoms does not exclude it as a cause.
  • The test is limited by the difficulty of excluding the possibility of environmental contamination, Still, the diatom test is considered as the ‘gold standard’ for diagnosis of ‘typical drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The femur (thigh bone) is the ideal sample for diatom testing in suspected drowning cases to confirm if the person was alive during submersion, as it provides a reliable and less contaminated source for detecting diatoms.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 372

choices.text: Jugular vein
Carotid artery
Vertebral artery
Both a and b

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following an assault where she was reported to have had pressure applied to her neck. She complains of dizziness and difficulty breathing. On examination, she exhibits signs of hypoxia and petechiae around her neck and face. The emergency physician notes that the amount of pressure applied to her neck during the assault was estimated to be about 6-7 kg. In this scenario, which of the following structures in her neck was most likely compressed due to the applied weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both a and b

 

Option D:

 

A weight of approximately 6 kg is sufficient to compress both the jugular vein and the carotid artery in the neck.

 

The jugular vein, being a low-pressure system, can be easily compressed, leading to venous congestion.

 

The carotid artery, with its critical role in supplying blood to the brain, can also be compressed with this amount of force, potentially causing cerebral ischemia and unconsciousness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: vertebral artery - The vertebral artery, due to its deeper location and protection by the cervical vertebrae, typically requires greater force for compression i.e. around 20 Kg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339

choices.text: Partial hanging
Complete hanging
Ligature strangulation
Both a & c

questions.text: In forensic pathology, the examination of ligature marks on the neck is essential for determining the cause of death. These marks can vary in their appearance depending on the manner of death. Horizontal ligature marks in the neck are typically seen in which of the following situations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both a & c

 

Option D:

 

Horizontal ligature marks in the neck are indicative of both partial hanging and ligature strangulation.

 

In partial hanging, the body's weight is unevenly distributed, often resulting in a horizontal mark.

 

Ligature strangulation, typically involving an assailant using a cord-like object, also tends to leave horizontal marks.

 

 

Postmortem findings in strangulation

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Complete hanging - Complete hanging, where the body is completely suspended, often leaves an oblique or V-shaped mark due to the body's weight being evenly distributed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horizontal ligature marks on the neck are seen in cases of partial hanging and ligature strangulation, providing critical clues in forensic investigations to differentiate these from complete hanging.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341

choices.text: Hanging
Strangulation by ligature
Throttling
Burking

questions.text: The forensic analysis of neck injuries is a vital component in determining the cause of death. The hyoid bone, a U-shaped bone in the neck, can fracture under certain circumstances. In which of the following situations is a hyoid bone fracture most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Throttling

 

Option C:

 

Hyoid bone fracture is most commonly associated with throttling, which is manual strangulation. It involves the use of hands to compress the neck, leading to a direct and forceful impact on the hyoid bone.

 

Throttling or Manual Strangulation - Asphyxia produced by compression of the neck by human hands. The cause of death is asphyxia from obstruction of respiration, Cerebral anoxia from interference with cerebral circulation, vagal inhibition from pressure on carotid nerve plexus consisting of fibers of vagus, sympathetic and glossopharyngeal nerves. About half of the deaths are due to vagal inhibition. Pressure must be applied for 2 minutes (min) or more to cause death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hanging: While the hyoid bone can be affected in hangings, fractures are less common because the force is usually distributed along the ligature rather than directly on the hyoid.

 

Option B: Strangulation by ligature: Similar to hanging, the force is distributed by the ligature and does not typically directly impact the hyoid bone to cause a fracture.

 

Option D: Burking: This involves a combination of suffocation and crushing of the chest. While it may involve neck compression, the mechanism is less likely to specifically cause hyoid bone fracture compared to throttling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone is the most diagnostic finding of throttling, which differentiates it from other causes of death such as hanging or strangulation by ligature. In contrast, hanging, whether by ligature or suspension, typically does not exert direct pressure on the hyoid bone. Strangulation by ligature and Burking (smothering and compressing the chest) are less likely to cause direct trauma to the hyoid bone compared to throttling.

 

Sequence of hyoid bone fracture: Throttling > hanging > ligature strangulation.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341

choices.text: Airway occlusion
Vasovagal shock
Fracture of upper cervical vertebra
Coma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male prisoner, sentenced to death, underwent execution by judicial hanging. The execution was performed with a calculated drop length. Upon autopsy, the forensic expert observed a specific finding with no signs of struggle or defensive injuries. Considering the mechanism of death in judicial hangings and the autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fracture of upper cervical vertebra

 

Option C:

 

In judicial hanging, the cause of death is predominantly due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae, particularly the fracture-dislocation of the C2 vertebra (axis), often referred to as a "hangman's fracture." This type of hanging is designed to cause a rapid fracture-dislocation of the neck, resulting in immediate unconsciousness and rapid death, primarily through spinal cord injury and disruption of the brainstem functions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Airway occlusion: While this can occur in hangings, it is not the primary mechanism in judicial hanging, which aims for a quick fracture of the neck.

 

Option B: Vasovagal shock: This is a less likely primary cause of death in judicial hangings, as the mechanism is designed to be quick and efficient.

 

Option D: Coma: Coma may result from the injury, but it is not the primary mechanism of death in judicial hanging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae, leading to immediate unconsciousness and rapid death due to spinal cord injury and brainstem disruption.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339

choices.text: Garrotting
Bansdola
Throttling
Mugging

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was found dead in a remote area near his farm. The local medical officer was called to the scene and noted a piece of cloth tied tightly around the man's neck with sticks inserted into the knot, applying a compressive force. There were no other signs of struggle or injury. The medical officer knows this finding is significant and characteristic of a specific type of asphyxial death. Which type of asphyxia does this scenario most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bansdola

 

Option B:

 

Bansdola: Strong bamboo is placed across the throat and another across the back of the neck. Both the ends are tied with a rope due to which the victim is squeezed to death.

 

Types of strangulation –

 

  1. Manual Strangulation
  2. Ligature strangulation 
  3. Mugging
  4. 4)Bansdola 
  5. Garrotting

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Garrotting: Ligature material is twisted with help of a lever. It is a special type of garroting where the ligature material is an iron collar twisted by a lever. It was a method of judicial execution in Spain. Image below shows Garrotting:

 

 

Option C: Throttling: When constriction is produced by the pressure of the fingers and palms upon the throat, it is called throttling.

 

Option D: Mugging: When strangulation is brought about by compressing the throat with a foot, knee, bend of elbow, or some other solid substances, it is known as mugging (stranglehold).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bansdola is a form of asphyxia where a piece of cloth or rope is tied around the neck and sticks are used to twist and tighten it, resulting in strangulation. This method is particularly noted for the use of sticks to apply compressive force.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 359

choices.text: Throttling
Burking
Ligature Strangulation
Hanging

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was found deceased in his home following a heated argument with his brother over property division. The casualty medical officer at a district hospital observed the deceased during the post-mortem examination. A radiological image revealed a distinct finding in the mandibular area, indicative of significant trauma. Given the context of a familial dispute and the radiological findings, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Throttling

 

Option A:

 

The picture in question shows the inward # of Hyoid bone. This is most commonly seen in throttling.

 

Neck injuries in Asphyxial deaths

 

  • Neck injuries indicate compression of neck.                                                                            
  • Common causes of compression of neck are manual strangulation (MS), ligature strangulation (LS) and Hanging (H)
  • Incidence of most neck injuries (e.g. Thyroid #, muscle injuries, larynx # etc) are MS > LS > H  
  • Exceptions:
    • Incidence of Hyoid #, Carotid artery tear: MS> H >LS
    • Incidence of Cervical Vertebrae # (C2-C3): Only Judicial hanging
  • Hyoid#:  
    • Overall incidence of Hyoid #: most common in MS
    • Internal # of Hyoid: Most common in MS
    • Outward # of Hyoid: Most common in Hanging

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Burking: It does not cause hyoid # or any other neck injury, as it is compression of chest and closure of mouth and nose. 

 

Option C: Ligature Strangulation: Hyoid # in LS is rare. It is much more common in MS.

 

Option D: Hanging: Hyoid # in hanging is outward # as shown below:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of an inward fracture of the hyoid bone is most commonly associated with throttling. Burking does not typically result in neck injuries, ligature strangulation rarely causes hyoid fractures, and hanging generally results in outward hyoid fractures. Understanding the pattern of neck injuries is crucial in forensic evaluations to determine the mechanism of death.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 357

choices.text: Typical Hanging
Atypical Hanging
Partial Hanging
Complete Hanging

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing case files with photographic evidence from various crime scenes. One of the photographs depicts a drawing of a body in a suspended state with a ligature mark running upward and then encircling the neck in a symmetrical pattern around the base of the skull, as shown below. Based on the ligature mark pattern, what type of hanging does the image most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Typical Hanging

 

Option A:

 

In the image the ligature runs from the midline above the thyroid cartilage, symmetrically upward on both side of neck to the occipital region, the point of suspension (knot of ligature) being on occiput (at nape of neck) which is characteristic for Typical hanging.

 

Hanging

 

Compression of the neck due to suspension of the body by means of a ligature in such a manner that the weight of the body (or a part of the body weight) acts as a constricting force.

 

Classification of Hanging

 

  1. On the basis of position of the knot - Typical and Atypical
  2. On the basis of degree of suspension - Complete and Incomplete/ partial Hanging

                             

Explanation:

 

Option B: Atypical Hanging -  Atypical hanging: Knot of ligature is anywhere other than on the occiput.

 

Option C: Partial Hanging - Lower part of the body is touching the ground (toes or feet touching the ground) or in sitting etc. Weight of the head acts as the constricting force.

 

Option D: Complete Hanging -  Body is fully suspended and no part of body touches the ground. Constricting force is weight of the body.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338

choices.text: Throttling
Ligature strangulation
Gagging
Hanging

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department of a medical college by paramedics after being found unresponsive in his home. The casualty medical officer notes that the patient has no pulse and is pronounced dead on arrival. The forensic expert conducts an autopsy and observes an oblique ligature mark located above the level of the thyroid cartilage. The subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark appears white and glistening. No other signs of struggle or trauma are present on the body. Considering these autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hanging  

 

Option D:

 

Ligature mark implies either hanging or ligature strangulation. The Ligature mark features in question are consistent with hanging.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Throttling: Throttling, or manual strangulation, involves the use of hands to compress the neck, which can cause a variety of injuries including intimal tears, due to the direct and forceful nature of the trauma applied to the neck structures, so do not have any ligature mark

 

Option B: Ligature strangulation: While ligature strangulation could potentially cause an intimal tear, it is more commonly associated with circumferential compression of the neck with a ligature mark, but the features are very different and is mentioned above

 

Option C: Gagging: Gagging is a form of asphyxia which results from pushing a gag (rolled up cloth or paper balls) into the mouth, sufficiently deep to block the pharynx. It combines the features of smothering and choking. So, it doesnot have any ligature mark

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to assess the ability to differentiate between various causes of asphyxial death based on autopsy findings. In this scenario, the oblique ligature mark above the thyroid cartilage, with specific subcutaneous tissue appearance and the absence of other injuries, points towards hanging as the cause of death.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338-341

choices.text: Drowning
Hanging
Morphine poisoning
Strangulation

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is found unresponsive on a beach and is brought to the nearest district hospital by the lifeguard. On examination by the medical officer, the patient is pronounced dead. During the external examination of the body, the medical officer notes the presence of fine, copious white froth at the mouth and nostrils that resembles shaving lather. The body shows no signs of significant external injuries, and there is no evidence of drug use or paraphernalia at the scene. Given the clinical findings and the circumstances in which the body was found, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drowning

 

Option A:

 

The presence of a fine, copious, white froth that resembles shaving lather at the mouth and nostrils is a characteristic antemortem finding in cases of drowning. This froth is caused by the mixing of mucus with air, water, and surfactant from the lungs and indicates that respiratory efforts were made while the individual was submerged in water, leading to this pathognomonic sign.

 

Froth in drowning has characteristic features

 

  • Large in amount
  • Persistent (will come again on chest compression)
  • Fine bubbles (do not readily collapse on touching with point of knife)
  • Whitish (sometimes Blood stained)
  • Lathery
  • Tenacious
  • Composition: Bronchial Mucus + proteinaceous exudate + surfactant mixed + water.

 

Froth may also occur in:

 

  • Opium Poisoning
  • Organophosphorous poisoning
  • Strangulation
  • Epileptic attacks
  • Acute pulmonary oedema
  • Electric shock.

 

In all these cases, froth is not fine, not of such large quantity or tenacious in nature as in drowning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hanging: This would more likely present with ligature marks on the neck and would not cause the frothy exudate seen in drowning.

 

Option C: Morphine poisoning: Overdose may lead to pulmonary edema, but the froth is usually not as fine & copious or 'shaving-lather' like as seen in drowning and would often be accompanied by evidence of drug use.

 

Option D: Strangulation: Similar to hanging, would present with signs of neck compression and would not produce the characteristic (fine & copious) frothy exudate seen in drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The goal is to recognize the significance of external findings in determining the cause of death. The presence of frothy exudate at the mouth and nostrils, especially when associated with a water setting, is highly suggestive of drowning and should prompt further investigation consistent with this cause of death.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 367

choices.text: Antemortem Drowning
Postmortem Drowning
Immersion in water
Electrocution in water

questions.text: A body is found by a fisherman in a freshwater lake in a remote area. The local medical officer is called to the scene to examine the body. During the external examination, he notes that the hair on the body's arms is erect, and there are no other visible signs of trauma or struggle. The body is otherwise well-preserved with no evidence of decomposition. Given the findings, which of the following is the most likely condition indicated by the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water

 

Option C:

 

The image shows puckered, granular appearance of skin and raised bumps on the skin as the hairs become erect, this is called Cutis Anserina. This happens due to contraction of erector pilorum muscles. Cutis Anserina just indicates immersion in water (Hence can be found in both antemortem and postmortem drowning).

 

Cutis anserine/goose skin

 

  • Definition: It is granular appearance of skin caused by contraction of erector pilorum muscles.
  • It can occur in both the living and dead:
    • Mechanism in Living: Cold water causes contraction of Erector pilorum muscles.
    • Mechanism in dead: Due to rigor mortis or due to contraction by cold water till 4 hrs after death while the muscles were still contractible.

 

Another feature which just indicates immersion in water (found in both antemortem and postmortem drowning) is Washerwoman’s hand / feet. Here the skin of the hands or feet shows a bleached, corrugated and sodden appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Antemortem Drowning and B. Postmortem Drowning: Cutis Anserina can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning, hence it is not a specific sign of antemortem or postmortem drowning.

 

Option D: Electrocution in water: Since electrical injury causes burns, blisters and wounds on the skin instead of cutis anserine, this can't be the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Goose flesh," "Goose pimples," or Cutis anserin is a temporary condition characterized by the erection of body hairs due to the contraction of small muscles at the base of each hair follicle. This reaction is most commonly a physiological response to cold. This can occur in both antemortem and postmortem conditions involving immersion in cold water.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368
